articles.headline: Global Food Crisis Tests Western Resolve to Retain Russia Sanctions
articles.snippet: With a food shortage threatening to create widespread famine, Western countries face a tough choice as sanctions exacerbate the problem.
articles.abstract: With a food shortage threatening to create widespread famine, Western countries face a tough choice as sanctions exacerbate the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Biden Irked by Democrats Who Won’t Take ‘Yes’ for an Answer on 2024
articles.snippet: The White House is trying to tamp down speculation about plans to seek re-election, while aides say President Biden is bristling at the persistent questions.
articles.abstract: The White House is trying to tamp down speculation about plans to seek re-election, while aides say President Biden is bristling at the persistent questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Earlier this month, when Senator Bernie Sanders said he would not challenge President Biden in 2024, Mr. Biden was so relieved he invited his former rival to dinner at the White House the next night.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: Companies Scramble to Work Out Policies Related to Employee Abortions
articles.snippet: Some have offered to cover travel and other expenses for employees, and are working to ease worker fears about safety and confidentiality.
articles.abstract: Some have offered to cover travel and other expenses for employees, and are working to ease worker fears about safety and confidentiality.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no clear blueprint for corporate engagement on abortion. After numerous companies came forward to announce that they would cover travel expenses for their employees to get abortions, executives have had to move swiftly to both sort out the mechanics of those policies and explain them to a work force concerned about confidentiality and safety.

articles.headline: Federal Agents Seized Phone of John Eastman, Key Figure in Jan. 6 Plan
articles.snippet: The action suggests that the criminal inquiry is accelerating into the efforts to help overturn the results of the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: The action suggests that the criminal inquiry is accelerating into the efforts to help overturn the results of the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal agents armed with a search warrant have seized the phone of John Eastman, a lawyer who advised former President Donald J. Trump on key elements of the effort to overturn the results of the 2020 election, according to a court filing by Mr. Eastman on Monday.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: U.S. Urges New Tactic to Curb Putin’s War Machine and Lower Fuel Prices
articles.snippet: Group of 7 leaders meeting in Germany were receptive to a Biden administration plan to cap the price of Russian oil in world markets, limiting Kremlin revenue.
articles.abstract: Group of 7 leaders meeting in Germany were receptive to a Biden administration plan to cap the price of Russian oil in world markets, limiting Kremlin revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRUN, Germany — Four months into Russia’s invasion, unprecedented Western economic retaliation and military aid to Ukraine have not curbed Vladimir V. Putin’s ability or apparent determination to wage war, leaving leaders of the world’s wealthiest democracies grasping for new ways to deter him.

articles.headline: At Least 46 Migrants Found Dead in Tractor-Trailer in San Antonio
articles.snippet: More than a dozen others were taken to local hospitals.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen others were taken to local hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The bodies of at least 46 people believed to be migrants who crossed into the United States from Mexico were found dead on Monday in and around a tractor-trailer that had been abandoned on the outskirts of San Antonio, state and city officials said.
articles.byline: By James Dobbins, J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval

articles.headline: Amid Attacks and Thefts, Some Retail Workers Want to Fight Back
articles.snippet: Assaults at stores have been increasing at a faster pace than the national average. Some workers are tired of fearing for their safety.
articles.abstract: Assaults at stores have been increasing at a faster pace than the national average. Some workers are tired of fearing for their safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Less Takeout, More Produce Swapping: How Inflation Is Altering People’s Behavior
articles.snippet: From driving fewer miles to downgrading vacations, Americans are making meaningful changes to their spending. Here’s how five households are coping with the highest inflation in decades.
articles.abstract: From driving fewer miles to downgrading vacations, Americans are making meaningful changes to their spending. Here’s how five households are coping with the highest inflation in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are suffering from sticker shock.

articles.headline: On Front Lines, Communication Breakdowns Prove Costly for Ukraine
articles.snippet: The Ukrainian Army has tried to modernize, but still falls short in coordination among units, so they often fight independently of one another — with sometimes deadly results.
articles.abstract: The Ukrainian Army has tried to modernize, but still falls short in coordination among units, so they often fight independently of one another — with sometimes deadly results.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOVIANSK, Ukraine — In the waning days of the battle for the eastern city of Sievierodonetsk, a Ukrainian National Guard sergeant had a problem: His platoon’s flank was exposed and he needed to tell his men the Russians were approaching.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

articles.headline: Ernst & Young to Pay $100 Million Fine After Auditors Cheated on Ethics Exams
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. said the cheating involved hundreds of the firm’s workers from 2017 to 2021, resulting in the largest penalty ever imposed by the agency against an auditing firm.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. said the cheating involved hundreds of the firm’s workers from 2017 to 2021, resulting in the largest penalty ever imposed by the agency against an auditing firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ernst & Young, one of the world’s largest auditing firms, has agreed to pay a $100 million fine after U.S. securities regulators found that hundreds of its auditors had cheated on various ethics exams they were required to obtain or maintain professional licenses — and that the firm did not do enough to stop the practice.
